Besides, choosing the best window size (preferably three sentences as citation context) could be suitable to convey the authors' sentiments (Alvarez and Gómez 2014). The citation labeling process is conducted manually in SCSA. Therefore, semi-automatic methods such as extracting important keywords and using semantic role labeling techniques may be better and less timeconsuming for citation annotation. For example, one of these methods is applied successfully in citation purpose classification (Abdullatif et al. 2015) and the researchers can adapt this method in SCSA.

div.head: Further research on citation classification and citation recommendation
div.p: The main drawback in citation classification is the lack of standard classification scheme for identifying the purpose of citations. Moreover, the annotation schemes are different and the researchers cannot compare their results and these schemes were annotated manually and domain specific. Another challenge is the complex process of manual feature extraction. Therefore, it requires building standard dataset to help researchers compare the performance of their methods. Developing and applying domain independent techniques and feature engineering can lead to improved classification results.

By going through the literature of citation recommendations, we come up with the observations that many researchers use partial list of references in their work to predict citations, yet some others focused on paper contents as well. Also, some researchers involved authors' behaviors along with citation habits and citation counts. One of the main drawbacks observed is lacking in capturing the contexts of the citations to find the relevance between context and cited documents. Therefore, NLP techniques should be applied to capture the context in a better way. Further, extracting semantic features from implicit and explicit citation may help citation recommendation process.

Further research on improving the SCSA model performance On the use of unsupervised machine learning methods, the majority of studies for solving SCSA issues have used supervised machine learning approaches such as SVM (Abu-Jbara et al. 2013;Athar 2011;Hernandez-Alvarez and Gomez 2015). However, these approaches have some limitations; feature selection process is one of the most important problems that have been used to train the classifiers. The performance of the classifier depends on the correct selection of the features. Therefore, unsupervised approaches seem to be useful to address some of SCSA challenges. For example, distribution representation methods such as word2vec (Mikolov et al. 2013) and dependency-based word embeddings (Wang et al. 2016) can handle the manual feature extraction in the previous SCSA literature. These methods can capture syntactic and semantic structure of citation context.

On the use of hybrid methods, another interesting trend is on the combination of machine learning and lexicon based methods. It can improve the classification performance as can be observed in other SA domains (Mudinas et al. 2012). We believe that hybrid methods could be an effective solution to address the limitations of the machine learning and lexicon based methods. For example, such solution could be use neural network models as proposed in Mikolov et al. (2013) for feature representation. This can handle the manual process of feature selection with ensemble learning approach. In addition, the hybridization of learning representation methods could be useful to improve the accuracy and quality of SCSA. For example, the combination of recurrent neural network with an attention mechanism for feature representation and then using supervised learning approach to perform citation polarity classification (Bing and Yang 2017).

On the use of deep learning, one of the most important limitations of machine-learning approaches is that their effectiveness depends on the set of selected features. However, typical feature selection approaches cannot address some phenomena, such as negation detection. One solution to address this is the using of algorithms that are capable of learning representations of the data known as deep-learning algorithms. The effectiveness of these algorithms on SCSA is still under-explored since there are only two studies that used deep learning method for polarity classification (Jochim and Schutze 2014;Munkhdalai et al. 2016). One of the interesting directions could be to examine the effectiveness of the recursive neural network deep-learning algorithms on SCSA and negation handling in the citation since they are effective on SA of standard text. Moreover, Since SA is a very semantic topic; machine learning models can be supported and improved by existing semantic resources such as WordNet-Affect and SenticNet4 lexicons (Strapparava and Valitutti 2004;Cambria et al. 2016) . The combination of linguistic knowledge derived from sentiment lexicons with deep learning models could be useful for improving citation polarity classification (Ebert 2017).

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Recent years have seen growing research interest in analyzing the content of academic publications, specifically the citation context. Mining authors' thoughts or sentiments in a large number of publications for different topics published every day in academic libraries is useful for improving citation analysis methods by considering the negative weight in its scheme.

Machine-learning techniques have been used for solving SCSA issues more than other techniques such as lexicon-based techniques. The SVM and NB classifiers have been the most frequently methods used for performing SCSA. Different kinds of features have been utilized with machine learning classifiers. One of the popular features is unigram which is a fundamental feature, and normally, researchers have used this feature as a baseline method for comparison purposes. Furthermore, researchers applied lexicon-based methods such as SentiWordNet to find terms that reveal sentiment and then classified the citation context into polarity levels. Deep learning methods have also been used to address the problem of feature selection in SCSA.

Our review provided an overview of the current SCSA methods. Most of the recent articles in SCSA field were classified and briefly explained. Following the analysis, it is quite obvious that SCSA is still an under-researched area. We examined the most prominent techniques for SCSA and reviewed common techniques to classify citation function and for citation recommendation. In addition, research resources that have been used in SCSA are also provided. Our survey offers an in-depth analysis of the current SCSA techniques, reviews several other trends, reveals interesting open issues, and highlights encouraging upcoming research directions.
